text: (gentle music)
- Hi, Shoaib.
Thank you so much for taking the time
to sit with me today.
- Thank you for the opportunity

to talk about the Brain
Knowledge Platform.
If we are able to achieve our goal,
we can understand how the brain works
and the structure of brain.

So we are trying to
build a single platform
to achieve all these goals.
And it's just not the Allen Institute,
but the entire neuroscience community.

- You know, as the science is
evolving, the data's evolving,
so what are some strategies

in terms of managing that data
as well as knowledge base?

- We are dealing with a very
large, vast amount of data.
We have close to 80 to 100 terabytes.

We assume that it'll go
to the exabytes level
in not a distant future.

The key challenge is that
all this data at times
are not similar to each other.
There's a lot of modalities in brain.
We are investing a lot

on the automation side
of data integrations
to validate the data coming in

and make sure that our data
models are very flexible.

Also, what's the best
way to search that data?

So we have invested in
our visualization tools,
which are very, very flexible.

- It certainly sounds like
having modular data architecture
and the flexibility is really important
for the Brain Knowledge Platform.
Will you tell me a little bit more
about the applications of AIML?
- You know, there's opportunities

that we can provide a
natural language interface
because not all our users
are really adept computer programmers,

and machine learning and
AI is really helping us

to find the connections
between this dataset
which are different from each other,
but has a missing piece of information
that's useful to complete the big picture.

- It certainly sounds
like the analytics layer

using AI and machine learning
is also very critical for BKP.
- Absolutely.
- It was amazing talking with you, Shoaib.
Thank you so much for your time.
- Thank you, Jenna.
(bright music swells and fades)
